When I'm inputting a link in the CMS for a picture for the homepage promos can't see what link is already there. Would be nice to rectify this, how long do you estimate this taking?
Thanks
Zara

Assistant New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Sorry for ignoring this one. It's actually a bit tricky to fix. Possibly more than a day.
Zara says: this is high priority and please spend up to one day to solve this.

Danny, I was just about to send this message, then I thought I'd better dbl-check why it's not assigned to anyone. Have there been any off-list discussions about this ticket? or is it still live?

=====
Hello, I'm sorry, for some reason this ticket was set to "Pending" which usually means we're waiting for input from you, so it dropped to the bottom of my in-tray.
Could you send a screenshot of the problem that you're describing please?
Thanks,
Kieran
Yes, it should not have been pending. My mistake.
Zara, could you send a screenshot of the problem that you're describing please? Many thanks.

comments.value:
Hi

I'm trying to add in new images to the Sports pages, and delete the existing mascot pictures and replace them with smaller thumbnails.
When I click delete the page dimensions change, and when I click insert, no image appears.

Have enclosed screen grabs to demo this.

Cheers
Zara

Zara Rabinowicz
Assistant New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.facebook.com/london2012
www.twitter.com/london2012

Ticket #2079 "inserting an image into body tex..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #2079: It appears 'choose a picture' widget is completely broken (not just when trying to add a picture to styled content.text).

Merging with #2179 which is the same story w/ more details.

Hi
If you could prioritize this ticket as important to be able to add and amend images in existing sports pages.
Cheers, Zara
Looking at this family of issues now.
This is going to be my weekend read: http://niichavo.wordpress.com/2009/01/06/contenteditable-div-cursor-position/
update?

This is a horrible timesink. Page editor is close to unacceptable in IE, especially when trying to deal with rich elements. It has quite a few browser hacks (instead of feature hacks), but I'm afraid it never worked perfectly on IE. I'd advise to use IE for just very basic text editing stuff and fall back for firefox for anything like this. The long term solution would be to cut down page editor features to half and code that reliably and/or have strict browser requirements.

Zara, we have spent quite a bit of time investigated this issue and the prognosis is not terribly good.

Internet Explorer has always been somewhat problematic for dealing with rich text editing. While it is fine for doing simple editing tasks, some things just do not work as well as we would like in IE. 

Getting picture deletion and uploading working properly in IE is likely to require a considerable amount of developer effort.

Our best advise (and I realise that this is suboptimal for you), is to fall back to Firefox for anything but the more simple editing tasks. If it is possible, we strongly recommend installing Firefox onto your PC.

Ticket #2208 "Inserting pictures into text" was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last comment in ticket #2208: Hi

I have tried to insert a picture into a text box (the body section) but it doesn't appear - we are using Internet Explorer.

It was on this page:
http://new2012.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/get-involved/education/international-inspiration/what-is-international-inspiration/index.php

Can you help?

thanks

Mairi

Ticket #1806 "Recurring problem" was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last comment in ticket #1806: It looks remarkably similar to #2178

Hi Danny

Thanks for this. I have Firefox and cvan work in that, but going forward when we have a bigger team and volunteers, they won't all have f/fox and that could cause issues at gametime. Could I get a quote/ timescale of how long it would take to fix this in IE?

Thanks, Zara
Jamie, over to you for this. I am assuming she doesn't actually mean games time itself. Or maybe she is not aware that delta tre are taking over before the games.

Given how tricky this will be to fix, it may actually make more sense to look at changing the templates where Zara is trying to assign images and seeing if we can use a <content:picture> container instead.

In short the inline images/editing stuff only has so much mileage and we could just be on a fruitless struggle trying to resolve it (the real answer is probably to re-write the page editor / rich text editor from the ground up, but as that isn't realistically going to happen this year, putting a time against this ticket to do that is rather pointless. In theory if we could get Michael in for a months he possible could rewrite it, but then I expect we'd end up with another two dozen new issues as a result of doing that).

Looking at the templates and how we could restructure them so we could use a <content:picture> container is however realistic, although a bit open ended / more a design issue.

Zara, apologies for taking so long to get back to you on this one, but this is a somewhat intractable problem, without a realistic timescale. 

However, there is another solution which we haven't mentioned: refactoring the page template so that instead of inline images, we place image containers in specific locations on the page. This may even be a better solution than allowing inline images if you are likely to have more people entering content over the next 12 months, because it enforces layout more than adding images inline on an ad hoc basis.

So, to summarize, the options are:

1. Use Firefox;

2. Refactor templates so that there are more pre-defined slots for image containers.
Zara, we have spent 2+ days on this over the last several months (mostly back in December/January). I am going to mark this as solved with one billable day on it, if that is OK with you.
But I don’t think it is actually working, is it?
No. That is correct.
Can you work with Tom on a more satisfying resolution (rather than ignoring the problem)? ☺

comments.value:
"it is always preferable to include a page’s primary keywords in a title tag, and considering the site’s poor ranking for Olympic- related keywords in the United States, it is vital to improve the title tag."

"Home Page Title Tag Recommendation: London 2012 Olympic Games Official Website | London2012.com"
Liz to decide what the rules should be.
Due date set as Jan 31.
Liz, I have done another sweep of tickets this morning and spotted this one. It should have been in a pending state, awaiting your attention.

comments.value:
See http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/1016

Jamie says: "The proper way is to do it is to add a lat/long to every event, you get this for free if you use the location picker in the CMS but not from user submitted events. Then when someone does a search we also turn the postcode they entered into a lat/long coordinate and then for each result returned use a bit of maths to work out the distance between the two points and therefore whether it falls within an acceptable radius."
Note: we think it it likely to be about 10 days' work.
Liz, this is relevant to the document "Open Weekend 2011 - Dec 2010" we just sent you. See "9. Refined search update listing (Postcode)".

subject: postcode searching, Part 2
description:
See http://postcms.zendesk.com/tickets/1016

Jamie says: "The proper way is to do it is to add a lat/long to every event, you get this for free if you use the location picker in the CMS but not from user submitted events. Then when someone does a search we also turn the postcode they entered into a lat/long coordinate and then for each result returned use a bit of maths to work out the distance between the two points and therefore whether it falls within an acceptable radius."

Shall we go ahead and do it..

(assuming the publication are adequately tagged up)

Jamie

make sure nothing 'gets lost'...

New Media Producer

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012 

________________________________
Liz wants to discuss this before proceeding.

Actually glad you raised that point Liz,

If we switch to a 'related' style navigation and drop the old manual navigation we will of course lose the old manual links (or rather it won't appear in the related nav unless it's related as the nav will now be automatic).

We could pull off a list of related documents/publication links for each before we start, but other than tagging there will be no way to force them into the side nav if they don't appear. Also remember that tagging is going to be less exact than some hand picked links. 

btw. Danny said "Liz wants to discuss this before proceeding" was the above what you wanted to discuss or something else?

That's what I wanted to discuss!

 

I think pulling off the list of documents/pub links for each page before
we start would be what we need to do. I think it's ok if we have to go
back and make sure the tags are as they should be, so long as we know
what docs we actually need to look for in order to match the tags. Does
that make sense?

 

How hard is it to get that list assembled?

 

Liz Goulding

New Media Producer

London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games

Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297

Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000

www.london2012.com  

www.twitter.com/london2012

[ignore the rest of the ticket, it's just this bit below I need help with!]

What's the best way of getting an export of the users if the website-link / publication-link fragments broken down by template / page.

Ideally as an Excel/CSV file, is this easy'ish to do? 

Feel free to bounce back some instructions ans get me to do it (I need to respond/to the rest of this ticket)

<content:repeat max="10"><content:text schema="hyperlink" id="website-link" isHidden="true"/></content:repeat>
<content:repeat max="10"><content:text schema="hyperlink" id="publication-link" isHidden="true"/></content:repeat>

* News article uses both theses, but so do a lot of other templates.
